newsitem.title: USA: Columbia Gas looking at range of alliances.
newsitem.headline: Columbia Gas looking at range of alliances.

text.p: Columbia Gas System, Inc is considering alliances or acquisitions covering a range of areas, including power generation, electricity marketing, natural gas transmission, and energy trading, CEO Oliver Richard said on Tuesday.
"We're probably looking at as many people as are looking at us," Richard said in an interview, declining to elaborate on which companies Columbia Gas was focusing on.
"I've always said if you're not a combination company, you should act like one," he said.
Restructuring of the electricity industry should offer new opportunities for building new natural gas-fired plants, acquiring existing plants or buying into a coal company.
"I'm very optimistic about whether or not there is a place for us in the unfolding electricity market," he said.
"We might take an equity interest in new plants or plants we may buy into," he said, adding that the company could also set up its own energy commodity trading group or acquire a trading unit.
Natural gas-fired power plants can be built more easily than other plants, which should give them an advantage in reacting to changes in power market demands, Richard said.
"When they need that niche marketing, we can jump in," he said. "I still think gas has a healthy upward on new load."
As electricity prices come down and competition increases from coal-fired power plant, Richard said that "it might make sense for us to be a partner with a coal company."
Columbia Gas has no specific plans to enlarge transmission capacity beyond existing plans to expand its transportation and storage services by 500 million cubic feet a day.

However, Richard said he would consider any opportunities that might arise with Trailblazer Pipeline in the Colorado area, which Columbia Gas co-owns with Enron Corp unit Northern Natural Gas Co and Occidental Petroleum Corp unit Natural Gas Pipeline Co of America.
Richard declined to predict how the company would do in the third quarter, when natural gas company earnings typically fall, except to say: "I think we're shaping up OK."
